financialTerms.definition: The amount of money a company owes to its creditors or suppliers for goods and services received.
The amount of money owed to a company by its customers for goods or services provided.
A resource with economic value that an individual, corporation, or country owns or controls with the expectation that it will provide future benefit.
A financial statement that summarizes a company's assets, liabilities, and shareholders' equity at a specific point in time.
Financial assets or the financial value of assets, such as funds held in deposit accounts, as well as the tangible machinery and production equipment used in environments such as manufacturing.
The total amount of money being transferred into and out of a business, especially as affecting liquidity.
The reduction in the value of an asset over time, due in particular to wear and tear.
The value of the shares issued by a company.
The cost required for something; the money spent on something.
A complete record of financial transactions over the life of a company.
A financial statement that shows a company's revenues and expenses over a specific period of time.
A company's legal financial debts or obligations that arise during the course of business operations.
A company's total earnings (or profit), calculated by subtracting expenses from revenues.
The income generated from normal business operations, usually from the sale of goods and services to customers.
A bookkeeping worksheet in which the balances of all ledgers are compiled into debit and credit account column totals that are equal.
An accounting method where revenue and expenses are recorded when they are earned or incurred, regardless of when cash is exchanged.
The point at which total revenue equals total costs, resulting in neither profit nor loss.
The direct costs attributable to the production of the goods sold by a company.
A portion of a company's earnings distributed to shareholders.
The profit a company makes after deducting the costs associated with making and selling its products.
A record of a financial transaction in the accounting system, showing the debit and credit accounts affected.
The ability of a company to meet its short-term financial obligations using its most liquid assets.
The profit realized from a business's core operations, excluding deductions of interest and taxes.
The portion of net income that is retained by the company rather than distributed to shareholders as dividends.
The difference between a company's current assets and current liabilities, used to fund day-to-day operations.
The process of gradually writing off the initial cost of an intangible asset over its useful life.
A financial plan for a defined period, often including estimated revenues, expenses, and cash flows.
A list of all the accounts used by a business to record financial transactions.
An entry recording an amount owed, typically on the left side of an account.
An entry recording an amount received, typically on the right side of an account.
A long-term tangible asset that is used in the operation of a business and is not expected to be converted into cash within a year.
An intangible asset that arises when a business is acquired for more than the fair value of its net identifiable assets.
The raw materials, work-in-progress, and finished goods that a company holds for the purpose of sale.
Ongoing business expenses not directly attributed to creating a product or service.
The total amount of wages and salaries paid by a company to its employees.
A measure of profitability calculated as net income divided by revenue, expressed as a percentage.
A performance measure used to evaluate the efficiency of an investment, calculated as net profit divided by the cost of the investment.
The total amount of tax debt owed by an individual, corporation, or other entity to a taxing authority.

financialRatios.definition: Net Income / Number of Outstanding Shares
Market Value per Share / Earnings per Share
Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) / Average Inventory
Net Credit Sales / Average Accounts Receivable
